title.children: BHP profits down 37pc, Coles profits up 4.8pc, ASX down in early trade

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market is having another lacklustre day after its worst weekly performance in a year last week, as investors worry about China and more possible rate rises in the US. The ASX 200 is down 0.1 per cent to 7,108, with consumer firms and energy stocks leading the sector losses. BHP and Coles are weighing on the market with investors disappointed with their profit results. Best and worst performers on the ASX 200: Altium +27.5% Megaport +21.75% Hub24 +15.1% Nanosonics -6.2% NIB -6.1% Coles -6%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX  in the red at midday

children.content: The Australian share market is having another lacklustre day after its worst weekly performance in a year last week, as investors worry about China and more possible rate rises in the US.
The ASX 200 is down 0.1 per cent to 7,108, with consumer firms and energy stocks leading the sector losses.
BHP and Coles are weighing on the market with investors disappointed with their profit results.
Best and worst performers on the ASX 200:
Altium +27.5%
Megaport +21.75%
Nanosonics -6.2%
Coles -6%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Oil and gas producer Woodside Energy has seen half-year net profit jump to a record $US1.74 billion ($2.71 billion) after it bought BHP's petroleum business. That comes after record half-year production of 91.3 million barrels of oil equivalent, and despite a fall in oil prices. Investors get an interim dividend of $US0.80 a share, down 27 per cent from the same time last year. Woodside says development of its major growth project, Scarborough, off the north-west coast of WA, is nearly 40 per cent complete. Chief executive Meg O'Neill says Woodside is continuing to investigate the death of a worker at its North Rankin platform in June, the first fatality at an offshore platform in Australia in more than ten years. “We have implemented changes to our operational practices based on the preliminary findings of those  investigations and shared our learnings with the broader industry," Ms O'Neill said. “Woodside’s safety performance over the past two years has been below the standard we set for ourselves.  We know we must do better and are resolved to strive for a return to leading safety performance."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Woodside profit jumps to record high

children.content: Oil and gas producer Woodside Energy has seen half-year net profit jump to a record $US1.74 billion ($2.71 billion) after it bought BHP's petroleum business.
That comes after record half-year production of 91.3 million barrels of oil equivalent, and despite a fall in oil prices.
Investors get an interim dividend of $US0.80 a share, down 27 per cent from the same time last year.
Woodside says development of its major growth project,
Scarborough
, off the north-west coast of WA, is nearly 40 per cent complete.

Chief executive Meg O'Neill says Woodside is continuing to investigate the death of a worker at its North Rankin platform in June, the first fatality at an offshore platform in Australia in more than ten years.
“We have implemented changes to our operational practices based on the preliminary findings of those  investigations and shared our learnings with the broader industry," Ms O'Neill said.

“Woodside’s safety performance over the past two years has been below the standard we set for ourselves.  We know we must do better and are resolved to strive for a return to leading safety performance."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Coles Group has reported its profits for 2023. It's posted a 4.8% increase in full-year profit, to $1.09 billion. Its financial results: Net profit after tax: up 4.8%, to $1.09 billion Sales revenue: up 5.9% to $40.5 billion EBITDA: up 3.8% to $3.38 billion Interim dividend per share: 36 cents Final dividend per share: 30 cents Total dividend per share: 66 cents James Graham, Coles Group chairman: "It is pleasing to record continuing sales growth and broadly stable after-tax profits from continuing operations in another year market by challenging operations. "The payment of a steady final dividend of 30 cents per share is in line with our 80 to 90 per cent full year dividend payout policy." The company achieve fourth-quarter sales growth of 8% in supermarkets and 2.9% in liquor.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Coles profits up 4.8% to $1.09 billion

children.content: Coles Group has reported its profits for 2023.
It's posted a
4.8% increase in full-year profit
, to
$1.09 billion.
Its financial results:
Net profit after tax: up 4.8%, to $1.09 billion
Sales revenue: up 5.9% to $40.5 billion
EBITDA: up 3.8% to $3.38 billion
Interim dividend per share: 36 cents
Final dividend per share: 30 cents
Total dividend per share: 66 cents
James Graham, Coles Group chairman:
"It is pleasing to record continuing sales growth and broadly stable after-tax profits from continuing operations in another year market by challenging operations.
"The payment of a steady final dividend of 30 cents per share is in line with our 80 to 90 per cent full year dividend payout policy."
The company achieve fourth-quarter sales growth of 8% in supermarkets and 2.9% in liquor.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: North Korea has told Japan it plans to launch a satellite in the coming days, possibly a second try to put a military spy satellite into orbit three months after its first effort failed. In late May, a North Korean rocket carrying a spy satellite plunged into the sea soon after liftoff, posing a setback to leader Kim Jong Un's push to establish a space-based surveillance system to better monitor the US and South Korea. North Korea vowed to make a second attempt after studying what went wrong with the first launch. Japan's coast guard said North Korean authorities notified it about a plan to launch a satellite from August 24 and the end of August 30. Coast guard spokesperson Hiromune Kikuchi said the notice didn't specify what type of satellite North Korea intends to launch but that he believes it possibly referrs to one similar to the spy satellite in the May launch. Reporting by AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: North Korea tells Japan of launch plan, a possible second try to put up spy satellite

props.alt: Cloud plumes from a rocket being launched.

children.content: (AP: Korean Central News Agency/Korea News Service)
North Korea has told Japan it plans to launch a satellite in the coming days, possibly a second try to put a military spy satellite into orbit three months after its first effort failed.
In late May, a
North Korean rocket carrying a spy satellite plunged into the sea
soon after liftoff, posing a setback to leader Kim Jong Un's push to establish a space-based surveillance system to better monitor the US and South Korea.
North Korea vowed to make a second attempt
after studying what went wrong with the first launch.
Japan's coast guard said North Korean authorities notified it about a plan
to launch a satellite from August
24 and the end of August 30.
Coast guard spokesperson Hiromune Kikuchi said the notice
didn't specify what type of satellite
North Korea intends to launch but that he believes it possibly referrs to one similar to the spy satellite in the May launch.
Reporting by AP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Adam Cranston, the son of a former deputy of the Australian Taxation Office, has been jailed for a maximum 15 years over his role in a $105 million tax evasion conspiracy. The 36-year-old was considered one of the "architects" of the fraud and was found guilty of two offences earlier this year, following a lengthy trial in the NSW Supreme Court. Between 2014 and 2017, a company called Plutus Payroll collected gross wages from employers before money that should have gone to the ATO by way of GST and Pay As You Go tax was syphoned via "second tier" companies. Justice Anthony Payne today found Cranston received at least $6.86 million from the scam, was "knowingly involved" from the outset, and was "intimately aware" of its criminal purpose. The judge handed him a head sentence of 15 years, with a non-parole period of 10 years.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Adam Cranston sentenced to 15 years for Plutus Payroll tax fraud

featuredLink.title: Live moment: An 'architect' of one of Australia's biggest tax frauds is set to be sentenced

children.content: Adam Cranston, the son of a former deputy of the Australian Taxation Office, has been jailed for a maximum 15 years over his role in a $105 million tax evasion conspiracy.
The 36-year-old was considered one of the "architects" of the fraud and was found guilty of two offences earlier this year, following a lengthy trial in the NSW Supreme Court.

Between 2014 and 2017, a company called Plutus Payroll collected gross wages from employers before money that should have gone to the ATO by way of GST and Pay As You Go tax was syphoned via "second tier" companies.
Justice Anthony Payne today found Cranston received at least $6.86 million from the scam, was "knowingly involved" from the outset, and was "intimately aware" of its criminal purpose.
The judge handed him a head sentence of 15 years, with a non-parole period of 10 years.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Japan will start releasing more than 1 million metric tonnes of treated radioactive water from the wrecked Fukushima nuclear power plant on August 24, putting into motion a plan that has drawn strong criticism from China. The plan, approved two years ago by the Japanese government as crucial to further decommissioning efforts at the plant, has also been opposed by local fishing groups, who fear reputational damage and a threat to their livelihood. Japan has maintained that the water release is safe. The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), the UN nuclear watchdog, also greenlighted the plan in July saying it met international standards and the impact it would have on people and the environment was "negligible." Japan says the water will be filtered to remove most radioactive elements except for tritium, an isotope of hydrogen that is difficult to separate from water. The treated water will be diluted to well below internationally approved levels of tritium before being released into the Pacific. Reporting by Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Japan to release Fukushima water into ocean in coming days

Japan has maintained that the water release is safe.
The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), the UN nuclear watchdog, also greenlighted the plan in July saying it met international standards and the
impact it would have on people
and the environment was "negligible."
Japan says the water will be
filtered to remove most radioactive elements

except for tritium, an isotope of hydrogen that is difficult to separate from water. The treated water will be diluted to well below internationally approved levels of tritium before being released into the Pacific.
Reporting by Reuters
